metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Trademark infringement by the defendants through the sale of counterfeit perfumes and fragrances bearing the plaintiff's trademark 'DAVIDOFF'.
Passing off by the defendants, where they are attempting to deceive consumers into believing that their products are affiliated with or endorsed by the plaintiff.
Copyright infringement, as the plaintiff alleges that the defendants are using their copyrighted materials without permission.
The plaintiff's claim of permanent injunction to restrain the defendants from further infringing their trademarks and copyrights.
The issue of jurisdiction, as the plaintiff is a foreign company and the defendants are operating in India, potentially raising questions about the court's authority to hear the case.
The defendants' potential defense of ignorance, as they claim to have been unaware of the counterfeit nature of the products they were selling.
The role of the website www.shopclues.com, operated by defendant no.3, in facilitating the sale of counterfeit products and potential liability for contributory infringement.
The plaintiff's claim of vast goodwill and reputation in the 'DAVIDOFF' trademark, and whether this is sufficient to establish a strong case for trademark protection.
The defendants' failure to respond to or comply with the cease and desist notice issued by the plaintiff, and how this may impact their defense.
The potential for damages or other remedies to be awarded to the plaintiff if the court finds in their favor.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: Zino Davidoff SA vs. Bhalani Enterprises & Ors.**

**Background:**
The plaintiff, Zino Davidoff SA, is a Swiss company that manufactures and sells perfumes and fragrances under the trademark "DAVIDOFF". The company has been using the trademark since 1984 and has registered it in various countries, including India. The defendants, Bhalani Enterprises and others, were allegedly selling counterfeit perfumes and fragrances bearing the "DAVIDOFF" trademark through the website www.shopclues.com.

**Legal Issues:**
The plaintiff filed a suit seeking permanent injunction to restrain the defendants from:

1. Infringing the plaintiff's trademarks and copyrights
2. Passing off their goods as those of the plaintiff
3. Selling counterfeit products under the "DAVIDOFF" trademark

The plaintiff claimed that the defendants' actions would cause irreparable loss and injury to their business and goodwill.

**Arguments:**
The plaintiff argued that they had a prima facie case for grant of ex parte injunction, as they had disclosed sufficient evidence to show that the defendants were selling counterfeit products under the "DAVIDOFF" trademark. The plaintiff also claimed that the balance of convenience was in their favor, as the defendants' actions would cause harm to their business and reputation.

The defendants, on the other hand, argued that they were not involved in the infringement activities and that the plaintiff had not provided sufficient evidence to support their claims.

**Court Findings:**
The court found that the plaintiff had indeed disclosed a prima facie case in their favor, as they had provided evidence of the defendants' infringing activities and the potential harm that these actions could cause to the plaintiff's business and reputation. The court also noted that the balance of convenience was in favor of the plaintiff, as the defendants' actions would cause irreparable loss and injury to the plaintiff.

**Decision:**
On January 17, 2023, the Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal granted an ex parte ad interim injunction in favor of the plaintiff, restraining the defendants from selling the impugned products under the "DAVIDOFF" trademark. The court's decision was based on the plaintiff's prima facie case and the potential harm that the defendants' actions could cause to the plaintiff's business and reputation.

**Key Takeaways:**

1. The court recognized the importance of protecting intellectual property rights, particularly in cases where counterfeit products are being sold.
2. The plaintiff's evidence of the defendants' infringing activities and the potential harm to their business and reputation was sufficient to support the grant of an ex parte ad interim injunction.
3. The balance of convenience was in favor of the plaintiff, as the defendants' actions would cause irreparable loss and injury to the plaintiff's business and reputation.

This decision highlights the importance of protecting intellectual property rights and the need for companies to take prompt action to prevent the sale of counterfeit products.

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
According to page 6 of the PDF "12. ZINO DAVIDOFF VS. BHALANI ENTERPRISES & ORS.pdf", the court has made the following decisions:

* The defendant no.2 has given an undertaking not to deal with the impugned products, and therefore, no damages and costs are awarded against them.
* The defendant no.1, who neither replied to the legal notice nor appeared in court, is found guilty of manufacturing and selling counterfeit 'DAVIDOFF' branded perfumes and fragrances.
* The court decrees the suit in favor of the plaintiff, Zino Davidoff SA, and orders the defendant no.1 to pay Rs.3,00,000/- in damages.
* The decision was made on January 17, 2023, by the High Court of Delhi, with the digitally signed order by Amit Bansal on January 21, 2023.
* The case number is CS(COMM) 460/2016, and the advocates involved are Mr. Ajay Amitabh Suman for the plaintiff and Ms. Snehima Jauhari with Mr. Sohrab for the defendants. (Source: 2023/DHC/000458)

‘DAVIDOFF’ or any other trademark deceptively similar to the 
‘DAVIDOFF’ marks of the plaintiff on the website, www.shopclues.com, or 
any other website in relation to the business of perfumes, fragrances and 
related products.   
16. 
In so far as the reliefs of damages and cost prayed for in the plaint, the 
defendant no.2 has given an undertaking not to deal with the impugned 
products vide reply dated 13th May, 2015 to the cease and desist notice. In 
my considered view, it is not the case of the plaintiff that after the aforesaid 
reply, the defendant no.2 continued to sell the impugned products. 
Therefore, I do not deem it proper to award damages and costs against the 
defendant no.2.    
17. 
As regards defendant no.1, the defendant no.1 neither replied to the 
legal notice, nor appeared before this Court. There can be no justification for 
manufacturing and selling perfumes and fragrances in counterfeit 
‘DAVIDOFF’ branded packaging. The use of the impugned products on 
human body can cause adverse reactions. Clearly, customers are being 
misled by the defendants no.1 and the entire effort is deliberate and 
dishonest. This amounts to dilution of the reputation and goodwill of the 
plaintiff’s trademarks and causing loss to the plaintiff in business and 
reputation. The defendant no.1 has been making unlawful gains at the 
expense of the plaintiff.  
18. 
In view of the foregoing facts and circumstances, this Court is of the 
view that this is not a case of innocent adoption by the defendant no.1. The 
Court cannot ignore such flagrant misuse of the plaintiff’s marks by the 
defendant no.1. Therefore, the suit is decreed in favour of the plaintiff for 
Rs.3,00,000/- towards damages to be paid by the defendant no.1.

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the Court Decision section of the PDF document "ZINO DAVIDOFF VS. BHALANI ENTERPRISES & ORS.pdf" (2023/DHC/000458), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi has made a decision in the case CS(COMM) 460/2016. The plaintiff, Zino Davidoff SA, was represented by Mr. Ajay Amitabh Suman, Advocate, while the defendants, Bhalani Enterprises & Ors, were represented by Ms. Snehima Jauhari with Mr. Sohrab.

The court has decreed the present suit against the defendant no.1 in terms of prayer clauses 'a', 'e', and 'g' of the plaint and against the defendant no.2 in terms of prayer clause 'a' of the plaint. The defendant no.1 has been ordered to pay Rs.2,00,000/- to the plaintiff as costs within eight weeks, failing which the plaintiff can commence execution proceedings.

The court has also accepted a Settlement Agreement dated 5th December, 2022, in relation to the defendant no.3, which shall form part of the decree. The plaintiff has chosen not to pursue reliefs contemplated in prayer clauses 'b', 'c', 'd', and 'f' of the plaint against the defendants no.1 and 2.

The decree sheet has been ordered to be drawn up, and all pending applications have been disposed of. The decision was made by AMIT BANSAL, J. on January 17, 2023, and digitally signed on January 21, 2023. The details of the case can be found in the PDF document "ZINO DAVIDOFF VS. BHALANI ENTERPRISES & ORS.pdf" (source: 2023/DHC/000458).
